channel.title: NPR Topics: News
channel.description: NPR news, audio, and podcasts. Coverage of breaking stories, national and world news, politics, business, science, technology, and extended coverage of major national and world events.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 NPR - For Personal Use Only

item.title: FAA to reduce air traffic by 10%. And, Trump administration plans to appeal SNAP ruling
item.description: The FAA plans to reduce air traffic by 10% at busy airports. And, a federal judge orders the Trump administration to fully restore SNAP food benefits by today, which it plans to appeal.
item.content:encoded:
The FAA plans to reduce air traffic by 10% at busy airports. And, a federal judge orders the Trump administration to fully restore SNAP food benefits by today, which it plans to appeal.

(Image credit: Mario Tama)
item.dc:creator: Brittney Melton

item.title: Under RFK Jr., the CDC is scrutinizing the childhood vaccine schedule
item.description: Health Secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr.'s Centers for Disease Control and Prevention has launched an unprecedented review of routine shots given to kids, alarming public health experts.
item.content:encoded:
Health Secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr.'s Centers for Disease Control and Prevention has launched an unprecedented review of routine shots given to kids, alarming public health experts.

(Image credit: Jan Sonnenmair)
item.dc:creator: Rob Stein

item.title: Support for Israel among U.S. conservatives is starting to crack. Here's why
item.description: For a decade, political support for Israel has come from conservative Christians. But now isolationism and antisemitism are changing the tone.
item.content:encoded:
For a decade, political support for Israel has come from conservative Christians. But now isolationism and antisemitism are changing the tone.

(Image credit: SOPA Images)
item.dc:creator: Geoff Brumfiel

item.title: What's happening with furniture prices? A tale of $399 couches and tariffs
item.description: Competition, whether from overseas rivals or second-hand goods, has kept the price of furniture relatively low. New tariffs may boost U.S. makers — and raise prices.
item.content:encoded:
Competition, whether from overseas rivals or second-hand goods, has kept the price of furniture relatively low. New tariffs may boost U.S. makers — and raise prices.

(Image credit: Getty Images)
item.dc:creator: Alina Selyukh

item.title: The shutdown continues, but politics persists. That gives this quiz a lot of fodder
item.description: Here are a bunch of questions about politics and one about bears.
item.content:encoded: Here are a bunch of questions about politics and one about bears.
item.dc:creator: Holly J. Morris

item.title: Want less screen-obsessed kids? Set better tech boundaries for yourself
item.description: There's a lot of talk about how to monitor screen time for kids. But for kids to have healthy relationships with technology and smartphones, parents need to model good habits. Here's how.
item.content:encoded: There's a lot of talk about how to monitor screen time for kids. But for kids to have healthy relationships with technology and smartphones, parents need to model good habits. Here's how.
item.dc:creator: Andee Tagle

item.title: If we're being truthful, people are saying 'honestly' all the time
item.description: The popularity of the word honestly online and in conversation has soared in recent years. TBH, we'd like to know what's going on.
item.content:encoded:
The popularity of the word honestly online and in conversation has soared in recent years. TBH, we'd like to know what's going on.

(Image credit: Yoshiyoshi Hirokawa)
item.dc:creator: L. Carol Ritchie

item.title: An NPR reporter's journey into Gaza, for the first time since the war began
item.description: NPR's Mideast correspondent Daniel Estrin has entered the Gaza Strip for the first time since the war began, but Israel still requires a military escort.
item.content:encoded:
NPR's Mideast correspondent Daniel Estrin has entered the Gaza Strip for the first time since the war began, but Israel still requires a military escort.

(Image credit: Daniel Estrin)
item.dc:creator: Daniel Estrin

item.title: Is the job market getting worse? As the shutdown continues, this is what we know
item.description: For the second month in a row, a government report on employment and unemployment has been delayed by the federal shutdown. That leaves analysts looking for other signs to gauge the job market.
item.content:encoded:
For the second month in a row, a government report on employment and unemployment has been delayed by the federal shutdown. That leaves analysts looking for other signs to gauge the job market.

(Image credit: Joe Raedle)
item.dc:creator: Scott Horsley

item.title: 'My first real role model': Two sisters remember their mother and her passing
item.description: Sisters Shanita Baraka Akintonde and Danielle Tavon Bishop remember their mother, Mary Catherine Bishop, and their final moments with her.
item.content:encoded: Sisters Shanita Baraka Akintonde and Danielle Tavon Bishop remember their mother, Mary Catherine Bishop, and their final moments with her.
item.dc:creator: Halle Hewitt
